description.en: Is this an LOV or a free-form text field?

helptext.en:
Enter the status of the record to indicate its completeness.

BCAP Submission Status

Select the appropriate option from the drop-down menu.

In Progress – record is in the process of being entered.

Submitted – record is complete and awaiting review.

Update Requested – existing record was edited and requires review.

Approved Basic Record – record reviewed and approved. Basic records only include enough information to have them on the BC Register and are ineligible for the Canadian Register.

Approved Full Record – record reviewed and approved. Full records include all the information required to be eligible for the Canadian Register.

Restricted/Unrestricted

Select the appropriate option. Restricted records do not appear to the public and are ineligible for the Canadian Register.

CRHP Submission Status

Select the appropriate option from the drop-down menu:

Ineligible – record is not eligible for the CRHP because it is restricted or does not have enough required information to be submitted to the CRHP.

Submitted – record is submitted to the CRHP and awaiting feedback or approval.

Update Required – record has been updated and needs to be resubmitted to CRHP.

Approved – record has been approved and is available on the Historic Places website.

Removed – record was previously listed on the CRHP but was removed.

Date Submitted to CRHP

Enter the most recent date the record was submitted to the CRHP.

Generate CRHP XML

Click to generate the xml to submit to the CRHP. Ensure all information is reviewed for accuracy and typos before generating, especially the SoS and Images info.

CRHP ID Number

Enter the federal ID number assigned upon record submission to the CRHP.

description.en: The legal description of a property in BC. (Is this the same across Canada?)

helptext.en:
Enter the legal property description information.

PID (Parcel Identifier) or PIN (Parcel Identification Number)

Enter the nine-digit Parcel Identifier (PID) or Parcel Number (PIN) that uniquely identifies a parcel in the land title register of BC.

Legal Description

Enter the full legal description of the property. The legal description usually consists of a lot number, various other descriptive numbers, and a plan number.

Example: LOT 1, BLOCK B, PLAN VIP16, SECTION 4, VICTORIA LAND DISTRICT

If the legal description has not been provided by a local government, copy it directly from one of these sources by searching civic address or PID number:

  • Cadastral Parcel Map Overlay
  • BC Assessment
  • Parcel Map BC

Legal Address Internal Notes

Add remarks specific to the legal address.

Add multiple entries as applicable.

Enter the civic address of the property or complete the “Location Description” if the site has no civic address.

Street Address

Use BC Address Geocoder to validate and standardize the address into a consistent format. Enter the address into the search box of the website and it will automatically suggest the correct address and abbreviate the street suffix. Copy and paste into the Street Address and City fields.

If the site occupies more than one street number, enter a range (e.g. 515-521 Hawkes Ave). If the site consists of multiple addresses that cannot be represented by a range, add separate address entries. If there is no number associated with the heritage site, enter the street name only (e.g. Fairfield Rd).

City

Enter the city of the heritage site.

Locality

Enter the established area or neighbourhood the site is located in, if identified by the Local Government.

Province

Default province is set to British Columbia.

Postal Code

Enter the postal code if known.

Location Description

Describe the location and extent of the site as concisely as possible for heritage sites that have no civic address (e.g. trails).

Examples:

Located at 800-block Wain Road, North Saanich

Located in central BC, 90 km east of Quesnel

Located in the east corner of park boundary

Located in Burrard Inlet, approximately 10 meters from shore southwest of First Narrows

 

Add multiple entries as applicable.

description.en: Represents a single node in a graph

helptext.en:
Define the spatial location of the site following the process below.

Spatial Location

Step 1: Confirm there is no existing record for the site located on the map before making a new site.

Step 2: Navigate to the site on the map box. Enter street address or city in the map search bar. Click “Edit” on the right-side panel.

Step 3: Define the Site Boundary using one of the following options:

  • Draw: Add a new feature for the Site Boundary whether that’s a point, line, or polygon and begin drawing the site boundaries in the map box using satellite imagery or other georeferences as a guide. Double click on the second last point to close a polygon.
  • Select Cadastral Feature: For “Select Cadastral Feature” turn on the Cadastral ParcelMap layer in the Overlays tab. Select the cadastral feature on the map and click “Copy Geometry.”
  • Upload Spatial Data: Upload a GeoJSON or KML file

Step 4: Saved geometry/geometries will appear as listed feature(s) that can be edited or deleted as necessary.

 

Accuracy Remarks

Describe how the site was digitized.

Examples:

Site digitized using shapefile; Site digitized using cadastral lot boundaries; Site digitized using satellite imagery

 

Source Notes

Describe the source of the spatial data.

Example: Submitted by Local Government

Define the spatial location of the site following the process below.

Spatial Location

Step 1: Confirm there is no existing record for the site located on the map before making a new site.

Step 2: Navigate to the site on the map box. Enter street address or city in the map search bar. Click “Edit” on the right-side panel.

Step 3: Define the Site Boundary using one of the following options:

  • Draw: Add a new feature for the Site Boundary whether that’s a point, line, or polygon and begin drawing the site boundaries in the map box using satellite imagery or other georeferences as a guide. Double click on the second last point to close a polygon.
  • Select Cadastral Feature: For “Select Cadastral Feature” turn on the Cadastral ParcelMap layer in the Overlays tab. Select the cadastral feature on the map and click “Copy Geometry.”
  • Upload Spatial Data: Upload a GeoJSON or KML file

Step 4: Saved geometry/geometries will appear as listed feature(s) that can be edited or deleted as necessary.

 

Accuracy Remarks

Describe how the site was digitized.

Examples:

Site digitized using shapefile; Site digitized using cadastral lot boundaries; Site digitized using satellite imagery

 

Source Notes

Describe the source of the spatial data.

Example: Submitted by Local Government

Enter the construction and/or significant dates associated with the heritage site. All dates in these fields are Common Era dates. Before Common Era dates can be included in the Statement of Significance.

Event

Select the appropriate event type.

Start Year and End Year

Enter the year in Start Year for a singular date and enter the year in End Year for a date range.

Circa

Mark the check box “Circa” to indicate whether the dates are approximate.

Source of Dates

Enter the source of the data, usually the government or agency name that submitted the date.

Chronology Notes

Enter additional remarks related to the events. When entering a “significant” date include a brief explanation, such as “Date Addition was constructed”.

Add multiple entries as applicable.

instructions.en: This is a placeholer for now. Is eveything except the Remarks, Photos & Documents historica data only?

helptext.en:
Define the designation or protection status.

Designation or Protection Start Date

Enter the date the site was formally recognized by Bylaw, Council Resolution, Order in Council, etc.

Designation or Protection End Date

Enter the date the site was no longer formally recognized or protected and add a note to explain the expiry. The end date is the date that the decision was enacted through any of the following:

  • De-designation or revocation
  • Cancellation of a Heritage Tax Exemption
  • Cancellation of a Heritage Revitalization Agreement
  • De-listing from a Community Heritage Register
  • Exclusion of Heritage Property from a Heritage Conservation Area
  • Etc.

Legislative Act

Select the relevant legislation that the site is formally recognized under. Either scroll through the options or start typing:

  • the authority (e.g. Provincial)
  • name of the act (e.g. Heritage Conservation Act)
  • the recognition type (e.g. Designation)

Government Name

Select the appropriate government authority that administered the recognition.

Reference Number

Enter how the decision was enacted and the corresponding reference number if applicable.

Examples: Bylaw 12-983; OIC 1946; Council Resolution (for Municipalities); Board Resolution (for Regional Districts)

Official Recognition Internal Notes

Add remarks related to the official recognition and specifically to explain an expiry date.

Example: Removed from Local Government Community Heritage Register 18 October 2012 due to fire that destroyed the building.

Add multiple entries as applicable.

description.en:
Captures information about special status, protection, or privileges afforded under law.

Applies to: Heritage Resource, Heritage Resource Model

helptext.en:
Enter the official recognition status.

 

Registration Status

Select the appropriation status information based on the following definitions.

Registered – the heritage site is officially recognized by a legislative enactment from the province, municipality, or regional district.

Federal Jurisdiction – The authority for the site is the federal government and is included for information purposes. It is not subject to provincial or local government legislation.

Recorded/Unprotected – a heritage site that has never been recognized or protected but is recorded for information purposes only.

Legacy – Use when the official recognition of the site was removed due to de-designation, destruction, removal from a Community Heritage Register, or otherwise no longer has reason to be on the official Register. Register type should be Non-Designated.

Cancelled Record – The record is cancelled when it’s determined to be obsolete, such as when the record is erroneous or when information has been moved to another record but the Borden number is retained for any associated files. This status is preferred over deleting records if it has been in existence for a while.

 

Officially Recognized

Yes – The heritage site is officially recognized and eligible for inclusion on the BC Archaeology Portal because its heritage value has been recognized or protected through a legislative enactment by the Province, municipality, or regional district. This selection also includes federally designated national heritage sites in BC for information purposes.

No – The heritage site is currently not officially recognized or protected. This includes de-designated heritage sites, revocations, and destroyed heritage sites. This selection also includes reported, non-designated heritage sites and structures, including sites in federal jurisdiction for information purposes.

 

Registry Types

Select the appropriate Registry type(s):

Agreement with First Nations - Heritage sites and objects protected by Sec 4, HCA

Archaeological Site - Sites automatically protected under Sec 12.1, HCA including: burial sites; Indigenous rock paintings; Indigenous rock carvings; Pre-1846 sites; heritage wrecks over 2 years old; and other archaeological sites as defined by regulation

CMT - Culturally Modified Trees

Heritage Wreck - Plane wrecks or shipwrecks over two years old as defined by Sec 12.1, HCA

Non-Designated Historic Site - Heritage sites recorded but not protected or recognized by any legislation

Palaeontological Site – Fossil sites

Prescribed Heritage Property - Heritage sites prescribed by regulation under Sec 3(1)(f), HCA. This includes Sec 18 sites.

Provincial Heritage Object - Objects protected under Sec 9, HCA

Provincial Heritage Site - Sites protected under Sec 9, HCA

Provincial Heritage Property - Heritage sites protected under Sec 11.1, HCA

Traditional Use Site – Non-archaeological, non-protected Indigenous sites such as berry picking areas, spiritual areas, etc.

Trail - Heritage trails

Select multiple registry types as applicable.

Enter any internal-only remarks.

Remark Type

Select an option from the drop-down menu.

General – Select for general remarks about record.

Duplicate Record – Select if the record is a duplicate and needs reconciling.

Incomplete Data – Select if there is incomplete data that needs resolving.

Restriction Reason – Select if the record is restricted and document the reason, such as owner requested removal.

Internal Remark

Enter the internal remark.

Remark Date

Enter the date the remark was made.

instructions.en: From Sergey's mock up. Where did this come from?

helptext.en:
Enter the Architects/Builders associated with the heritage site.

Name

Enter the first and last name of an architect or builder.

Type

Select the appropriate type from the drop-down menu.

Architect / Designer  - Refers to an architect, architectural firm, engineer, or designer. The architect/designer is the person or firm responsible for the design and/or production of plans for any buildings or other contributing resources of the site.

Builder - Refers to the individual(s) or firm(s) that contributed to the construction of a building or other contributing resources of the site, including elements created by craftspeople or artisans (e.g. stained glass work).

Architects/Builders Notes

Provide any additional comments about the architect/builder.

Add multiple entries as applicable.

Enter the site name to be the “Common” name. This is mandatory for all sites.

Make additional entries for all “Other” names. This is optional for all sites.

 

Site Name

The heritage site name should be concise and well known to the public to facilitate its searchability on the register. Site names can reference an address, location, current or historic use, event, person, or organization. Local Governments are responsible for providing names of municipal sites. If a name is not provided, use the address.

 

Name Type

Select the appropriate name type from the drop-down menu.

Common – This is the most recognizable site name to the public and will be the primary name that appears in the register.

Other – These are other recognizable or historic names for the site.

Enter any external URLs associated with the heritage site.

Only include links that directly relate to the heritage site’s history and value and not commercial links. It is strongly recommended that only long-term stable URLs are provided to avoid inactive links.

External URL Type

Select URL type from the drop-down menu.

Link Text (Optional)

Type the text that will be visible to the reader from the record view page. Clicking the link text will send the reader to the specified URL Address.

Example: Chinese Gardens, Rossland Heritage Commission

URL for link

Enter the URL Address.

instructions.en: Enter any external URLs associated with this Historic Place
What is the intention of this card?

helptext.en:
Enter information relevant to each individual image. Select an image from the image list to edit.

Primary Image

Select one primary image from the image list for the site.

Submit to CRHP

Select up to three images from the image list to submit to the Canadian Register of Historic Places (CRHP).

Image Type

Select one of the following:

Historical -  Historical images are images that were created in the contextual past and usually for a purpose other than documenting the historic place.

Contemporary - Contemporary images are images that have been created recently and generally for

Image View

Select the view that best describes the image. Either scroll through the options or start typing.

You can select one of the high-level general descriptors (below) or a more specific view option.

Interior - Refers to an image that depicts the inside of a building, structure, or object that has interior and exterior spaces.

Exterior - Refers to an image that depicts the exterior of a building, structure, or object that has interior and exterior spaces.

Landscape - Refers to an image that depicts the visible features of an area and can include natural and/or built components.

To further describe the image, you may select a sub-view option.

Aerial view - Refers to views achieved by creating the image from a high location such as a drone or aircraft.

Back view – Refers to depiction of the back of a subject such as the back façade of a building.

Close view – Refers to view where the emphasis is on the proximity of the subject as a whole.

Corner view – Refers to a view of a subject from (roughly) a ¾ angle or directly out from a corner.

Detail view – Refers to an image containing a partial view that focuses on a particular piece of the whole.

Distant view – Refers to an image created at a distance, typically showing the overall layout, design, or plan.

Front view – Refers to an image depicting the front of a subject.

Left side view – Refers to an image depicting the left side of a subject, from the perspective of the subject.

Overhead view – Refers to depictions with a vantage point above the subject.

Right side view – Refers to an image depicting the right side of a subject, from the perspective of the subject.

Image Feature(s)

Enter any additional information that would help describe the central subject(s) of the image such as the object of interest for details or room name for interior, etc. This field is optional.

Image Date

Enter the year that the image was created.

Image Description

Enter the full description of the content of the image including site name and/or street address.

Example: View of the front entrance of Point Ellice House and gardens in summer.

Photographer

Enter the first and last name of the photographer.

Copyright

Enter the name of the copyright holder or the name of the owning institution (often government name). Optional information (if known) can include: the name of the photographer, the year the original image was created, and the item number assigned by the holding institution.

Example: Heritage Branch, Ministry of Tourism, Arts & Culture, 2018

Attach digital documents with information relating to the site.

Document Type

Select the appropriate document type.

Document Description

Provide a short description of the document content (e.g. Bylaw)
